dataset.title: Age, Growth, and Reproduction of the Sculpin (Cottus beldingi) in Sagehen Creek, Nevada-Sierra Counties, California

creator.organizationName: University of California Natural Reserve System

abstract.para: MASTERS THESIS: Research at the Sagehen Creek project is designed to determine distribution and abundance in relation to cyclic fluctuations of fishes in high mountain streams which are subject to extremes in environmental conditions. In conjunction with this goal, life histories of the various species present in Sagehen Creek are being studied. The present study supplies basic facts which can be used in an analysis of the ecological role of the sculpin in Sagehen Creek.

intellectualRights.para: Obtain permission from data set owner(s)

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Sagehen Creek is a tributary to the Little Truckee River, which drains the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada in Nevada-Sierra counties, California.

section.title: Methods
section.para: The diversion and pumping method of population estimation was used on each stream section once per year. Random samples of the total sculpin population in each section were preserved. Samples of sculpin were also collected by seining in section VI. Sculpin abundance was estimated. Length, weight, age (otolith rings), and sex of each sculpin was recorded and analyzed.Seasonal growth of sculpin was followed via seining and pump-drain stream diversion.

Duration of the spawning season was established by observing ripe, spawning, and spent fish and studying maturing ova from month to month. Relation between fecundity and size of fish was analyzed. Potential egg deposition and development of ovaries was studied.
A critique of the Otolith aging method is included.

description.para: Annual diversion and pumping: August 12- September 4, 1953. Seining between May 2, 1953-January 25, 1954. Seasonal growth was followed from May 1953- January 1954.

samplingDescription.para: Ten stream sample sections were established on the creek at one mile intervals.
